results.headline: Unsung Heroines of Liberia, Making Guns Yield to Words
results.summary_short: Uplifting, disheartening, inspiring, enraging — the mind reels while watching the documentary “Pray the Devil Back to Hell.”
results.display_title: Pray the Devil Back to Hell

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pray the Devil Back to Hell

results.headline: Horror Through a Child’s Eyes
results.summary_short: See the Holocaust trivialized, glossed over, kitsched up, commercially exploited and hijacked for a tragedy about a Nazi family. Better yet and in all sincerity: don’t.
results.display_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Boy in the Striped Pajamas

results.headline: Duck! The Penguins Are Flying the Plane
results.summary_short: There’s a generally more diverting entertainment waddling along the edges of “Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa” than the larger one lollygagging on screen.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa

results.headline: It’s All About Him, No Matter Who He Claims to Be
results.summary_short: “JCVD” more often aims for a knowing, cerebral mood, allowing its hero moments of moody contemplation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of JCVD

results.headline: Predators and Young Prey in a World Gone Sinister
results.summary_short: “Gardens of the Night” is a harrowing story of kidnapping and forced child prostitution that conjures a world entirely populated by predators and prey.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gardens of the Night

results.headline: Intimate Table Talk for All to Ponder
results.summary_short: The phrase “divorced couple” sounds like an oxymoron, but there’s really no other way to describe the Dutch ex-spouses whose table talk dominates “Stages.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stages

results.headline: Beware of the Darkness, and Those Ugly Clothes
results.summary_short: God and Satan duke it out for the soul of a young girl in “The Haunting of Molly Hartley,” an unexpectedly cynical addition to the teen-scream genre.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Haunting of Molly Hartley

results.headline: Skin Flick? Nah, It’s a Love Story
results.summary_short: “Zack and Miri Make a Porno,” in spite of its lewdness, follows a gee-whiz romantic-comedy formula that would not be out of place on the Disney Channel.
results.display_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zack and Miri Make a Porno

results.headline: All the Life Surrounding Death in the Afternoon
results.summary_short: Stripping away centuries of civilization, “The Matador” confronts something primal in human nature, daring us to do the same.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Matador

results.headline: In Search of Family History Despite the Threat of Pain
results.summary_short: “One Day You’ll Understand” contains no great revelations or surprises, but rather is suffused with a quiet glow of sympathy and enlightenment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Day You'll Understand

results.headline: United by Shared Ambivalence
results.summary_short: “Monks: The Transatlantic Feedback,” an ambitious but unfocused documentary, bids to immortalize this short-lived if influential group.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monks: The Transatlantic Feedback

results.headline: The Evil Dumb
results.summary_short: In “My Name Is Bruce,” a silly horror comedy that only a cultist could love, Bruce Campbell, the star of countless B-movie thrillers, mercilessly spoofs himself.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Name is Bruce

results.headline: Night of the Living Spastic, Ravenous Porcupine Flesh-Eaters
results.summary_short: With “Splinter,” the director Toby Wilkins honors the conventions of the horror genre with skill and enough wit to keep the scares sharp.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Splinter

results.headline: A Provocative Story of Loss
results.summary_short: It is impossible not to be fired up by Kurt Kuenne’s incendiary cri de coeur, “Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father.”
results.display_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father

results.headline: Tale of a Marathon and Its Guiding Hand
results.summary_short: A new documentary offers a salutary and touching reminder that the race, like nearly everything else great about New York City, was the creation of a stubborn visionary.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Run For Your Life

results.headline: Immigrant Hoop Dreams
results.summary_short: “The First Basket,” a functional (if narrowly interesting) recollects the rich history of Jewish participation in basketball.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The First Basket

results.headline: Grand Guignol, by Way of the Tool Shed
results.summary_short: The latest and least of the “Saw” films is just plain boring and even a little tame — albeit by the standards of a genre that helped bring the phrase “torture porn” into the lexicon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saw V

results.headline: Bollywood: Often Energetic, Now Animated
results.summary_short: “Roadside Romeo” is something new under the Bollywood sun: sophisticated computer-generated animation that uses stars to voice the characters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Roadside Romeo

results.headline: Lost Luggage Is the Least of Their Worries
results.summary_short: “Passengers” is a supernatural thriller so mechanically inept and lacking in suspense that it doesn’t even pass muster as lowbrow Halloween-ready entertainment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Passengers

results.headline: A Broken Soul Wandering Aimlessly on the Long Path to Redemption
results.summary_short: In the drama “I’ve Loved You So Long,” Kristin Scott Thomas’s furious honesty rules out easy, unearned redemption.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I've Loved You So Long
